paper_analysis.claim: XBRL-Agent is the first LLM-based agent designed to analyze XBRL reports.

evidence.evidence_text: The paper presents XBRL-Agent as a LLM-based agent specifically designed to analyze XBRL reports, marking it as the first of its kind with empirical evaluation of its performance through extensive experiments.
evidence.limitations: Limited financial domain knowledge and mathematical capabilities of existing LLMs were identified as key challenges.
evidence.location: Section 5 - Performance Evaluation & Section 6 - Conclusion and Future Work
evidence.exact_quote: In this paper, we introduce the first LLM-based agent specifically designed to analyze XBRL reports, called XBRL-Agent. Our research empirically evaluates the performance of LLMs in analyzing XBRL reports and identifies crucial limitations in their current capabilities. Notably, existing LLMs exhibit significant deficiencies in expertise in the financial domain and mathematical capabilities when analyzing XBRL reports. To address these limitations, we propose two enhancement methods: 1) incorporating supplementary financial knowledge using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) technology [26], and 2) incorporating specialized tools such as a financial calculator. Our findings demonstrate that these enhancements substantially improve the performance of LLMs in XBRL report analysis.

evidence_locations: Section 5 - Performance Evaluation & Section 6 - Conclusion and Future Work

conclusion.author_conclusion: The XBRL-Agent significantly enhances LLMs' performance in analyzing XBRL reports by addressing deficiencies in domain knowledge and mathematical abilities. This is achieved through the integration of a retriever for improved domain knowledge retrieval and a financial calculator for enhanced numerical processing.
conclusion.robustness_analysis: The evidence is robust, with experiments showing marked improvements in domain query tasks and numerical calculations. The synergy of the retriever and calculator tools yields the most comprehensive improvements, particularly in complex numeric query tasks. This demonstrates a methodological strength in addressing LLM deficiencies with tailored tool integration.
conclusion.limitations: Despite substantive enhancements, mathematical analysis remains challenging for LLMs. Future research directions include advancing LLMs' mathematical capabilities and incorporating comprehensive financial domain knowledge graphs to address global variations in accounting standards.
